Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Small: Automatic Detection of Protocol Manipulation Attacks in Large Scale Distributed Systems Implementations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The main research focus of this proposal is to create a platform that allows to automatically find attacks in unmodified binaries of distributed systems. The attacks are conducted through message manipulation by insider attackers and impact primarily performance and availability. The platform combines existent open-source virtualization environments such as KVM, and network simulation and emulation tools such as NS3, to create a realistic environment in which target systems will run. The platform is general, scalable, and can be used for testing a large variety of distributed systems such as intrusion-tolerant and peer-to-peer systems.

The platform will improve the trust that distributed systems work according to their intended specifications in spite of faults, misconfigurations, or attacks.
The platform can serve as a tool for system developers from industry, government labs, and academia to test their systems. In addition, it can be used for programing exercises for distributed systems and computer security courses at both undergraduate and graduate level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This project has as main goal developing algorithms, frameworks and methodologies for automated testing and attack finding for distributed systems and network protocols. We had to address several challenges such as scalability with the search space, generalizability of the result to implementations in many languages and operating systems, capturing real-world conditions, and modeling realistic atackers. We created several algorithms for automated generation of attacks based on minimal information about the protocol design, several attack injection techniques that trade-off complexity for increased coverage, and several attack finding algorithms that trade-off increased implementation complexity to efficiency and wider coverage. We combined network emulation with virtualization together with these attack scenario generation, injection and finding algorithms to design and build several frameworks (Turret, Turret-W, and SNAKE) that provide automated testing and attack finding for distributed systems and network protocols. We used these frameworks to find  bugs and attacks in state machine replication services, message dissemination protocols with performance guarantees, wireless routing protocols, and transport protocols.

 

Broad impact

The grant contributed to the education of several graduate and undergraduate students; two of these students were women, with one of them being the lead student of the project.

State machine replication, messaging dissemination, routing, and transport protocols represent the backbone that enables comunication for all applications we use today over the Internet. The frameworks we developed in this grant helped making these protocols more robust to misconfiguration, failures, and attacks, thus increasing our trust in these protocols and ultimately improving the availaibility and security of the applications running on top of them.
